text: My aha moment of the value of first principles thinking was when I was at Dropbox. We would hire a ton of really smart people that had never done sales and had them do sales. There are a lot of disadvantages to that, but I do think it led to a ton of innovation. That's how we got our very innovative go-to market motions because a lot of those people then moved into different functions at the company. They had all this context on who the user was. They had talked to so many different users at that point. If you take people that are just super smart, they've never done it before, one advantage of that is they can innovate because I think they come in with, I don't know anything. Let me just figure this out.
speaker: Melissa Tan
context: Lenny asks Melissa for an example of first principles thinking in action. Melissa explains how Dropbox unconventionally hired very smart people with no sales experience to do sales roles. While this approach had disadvantages, it created unexpected innovation in their go-to-market strategies because these newcomers approached problems without preconceived notions about 'how things should be done.'
text_ko: 제가 Dropbox에 있을 때 근본 원리 사고(first principles thinking)의 가치가 확 확 느껴졌어요. 우리는 영업을 해본 적 없는 정말 똑똑한 사람들을 대거 뽑아 영업을 시키곤 했어요. 단점이 많긴 했지만, 그 과정이 엄청난 혁신을 불러왔다고 생각해요. 그렇게 해서 아주 창의적인 시장 진출 방식(go-to-market motions)이 나오게 됐죠. 많은 사람들이 회사에서 다른 역할로 이동하면서 사용자에 대한 맥락을 다 갖게 되었고, 그때까지 정말 다양한 사용자와 많이 이야기했거든요. 단지 엄청 똑똑한데 경험은 없는 사람들을 데려오면 한 가지 큰 장점이 있어요. 스스로 ‘아무것도 모른다. 그냥 해보면서 알아내자’라는 마음으로 들어오니까 혁신을 만들어낼 수 있더라고요.
text_zh: 我在Dropbox的时候突然想明白了第一性原理思维(first principles thinking)的价值。我们当时会招一堆特别聪明但完全没做过销售的人来做销售。这样做确实有不少弊端，但我觉得也带来了很多创新。我们那些很有创新性的市场策略(go-to market motions)就是这么来的，因为很多这样的人后来转到了公司其他部门。他们对用户是谁有很深的了解，跟各种各样的用户都聊过。如果你找那些特别聪明但从来没做过这件事的人，好处就是他们能创新，因为他们会想"我什么都不懂，那就自己琢磨琢磨吧"。
text_es: Mi momento de revelación sobre el valor del pensamiento desde principios básicos (first principles thinking) fue cuando estaba en Dropbox. Contratábamos un montón de gente súper inteligente que nunca había hecho ventas y los poníamos a vender. Eso tiene muchas desventajas, pero creo que nos llevó a innovar muchísimo. Así fue como desarrollamos estrategias de salida al mercado (go-to-market) súper innovadoras, porque muchas de esas personas después se movieron a diferentes áreas de la empresa. Tenían todo ese contexto de quién era el usuario. Habían hablado con tantos usuarios diferentes para ese momento. Si tomas gente que es súper inteligente pero que nunca lo ha hecho antes, una ventaja es que pueden innovar porque llegan con esa mentalidad de "no sé nada de esto, déjame descifrar cómo funciona."

text: I think the things that Dropbox got right, one of them was definitely hiring. So when I think about 2013, Dropbox was actually known in the tech circles as a place that was very selective, very difficult to get into. You could have an amazing resume, and Dropbox was really selective about the type of people they brought in. So I think they looked for two main things. They looked for first principles thinkers, so not necessarily your experience, but how do you approach problems, how do you know the right questions to ask? And then create your own framework around that.
speaker: Melissa Tan
context: Lenny asks Melissa about what Dropbox did right during their growth phase from 2013-2017. Melissa explains that Dropbox's hiring philosophy focused on two key traits rather than just experience: first principles thinking (the ability to approach problems from scratch and ask the right questions) and being collaborative team players. This selective hiring approach, despite candidates having strong resumes, helped drive innovation throughout the company.
text_ko: 제 생각에 드롭박스가 잘한 것 중 하나는 채용이에요. 2013년을 떠올리면, 드롭박스는 기술 업계에서 매우 선별적이고 들어가기 힘든 곳으로 알려져 있었어요. 이력서가 아무리 훌륭해도 드롭박스는 어떤 사람을 뽑을지에 대해 굉장히 까다롭게 골랐어요. 제가 보기엔 그들이 주로 본 건 두 가지였어요. 첫째는 근본 원리에서 출발해 생각하는 사람들 (first-principles thinkers)이에요. 즉, 단순히 경력 자체가 중요한 게 아니라 문제에 어떻게 접근하는지, 어떤 질문을 던져야 할지를 아는지 — 그리고 그걸 바탕으로 자신만의 프레임워크 (framework)를 만드는지였어요.
text_zh: 我觉得Dropbox做得特别对的一件事，就是他们的招人策略。你想想2013年那会儿，Dropbox在科技圈里是出了名的挑，特别难进。哪怕你简历再漂亮，他们对人的要求也是相当严格的。我觉得他们主要看两个方面：一个是要会从根本上思考问题的人，也就是说不光看你的工作经验，更看你怎么解决问题，知不知道该问什么关键问题；然后在这基础上，能不能建立起自己的一套思路和方法。
text_es: Creo que una de las cosas que Dropbox hizo súper bien fue el tema de contratación. Si me pongo a pensar en el 2013, Dropbox ya tenía fama en los círculos tech de ser un lugar súper selectivo, súper difícil de entrar. Podías tener un currículum impresionante, y aun así Dropbox era muy exigente con el tipo de gente que traían al equipo. Entonces creo que buscaban dos cosas principales. Primero, buscaban gente que pensara desde primeros principios (first principles thinkers), o sea, no necesariamente tu experiencia, sino cómo abordas los problemas, cómo sabes hacer las preguntas correctas. Y después que pudieras crear tu propio marco de trabajo alrededor de eso.

text: I don't think that they're mutually exclusive of each other because I think the other thing that I really emphasize on my team is being very results oriented. So as a growth leader, for better or for worse, everything you do is very measurable. And so I actually think this is why a lot of folks on my team, something that they actually appreciate is knowing what success looks like and knowing how they'll be measured. And I actually create a very results-oriented culture on the team where it's clear what our goals are, we break it down into the individual levers, it's clear how success is measured for each individual.
speaker: Melissa Tan
context: Lenny asks whether deeply caring about people and driving business impact are competing priorities for leaders. Melissa argues they can coexist by being very results-oriented while still caring about team members. She explains that in growth roles, everything is measurable, so she creates clarity around goals and success metrics while also supporting people's career development and giving them feedback.
vocabulary_highlights: break it down into the individual levers
text_ko: 이 둘이 서로 배타적이라고는 생각하지 않아요. 제 팀에서 특히 강조하는 건 매우 결과 지향적(results-oriented)이라는 점이에요. 그리고 그로스 리더(growth leader)로서, 좋든 나쁘든 하는 모든 일은 측정 가능(measurable)해요. 그래서 제 팀원들이 실제로 좋아하는 것 중 하나는 성공이 어떤 모습인지와 어떻게 평가되는지를 분명히 아는 거예요. 저는 목표가 분명한 결과 지향(results-oriented) 문화를 팀에 만들고, 목표를 개별 레버(levers)로 세분화해서 각 개인의 성공이 어떻게 측정되는지 명확히 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得这两个东西并不冲突，因为我在团队里特别强调的另一点就是要以结果为导向。作为一个增长负责人，不管怎么说，你做的每件事都是可以量化的。所以我觉得这就是为什么我团队里很多人其实很appreciate一点——他们知道成功长什么样，也知道会用什么标准来衡量他们。我确实在团队里营造了一种非常以结果为导向的文化，大家都清楚我们的目标是什么，我们会把目标拆解成各个具体的抓手，每个人的成功标准也都很明确。
text_es: No creo que sean cosas que se excluyan mutuamente porque algo que realmente enfatizo mucho con mi equipo es estar muy enfocados en los resultados. Como líder de crecimiento, para bien o para mal, todo lo que haces se puede medir muy claramente. Y por eso creo que muchas personas de mi equipo realmente valoran saber cómo se ve el éxito y entender cómo van a ser evaluados. En realidad creo una cultura muy orientada a resultados en el equipo donde está súper claro cuáles son nuestros objetivos, los desglosamos en las palancas individuales (individual levers), y queda claro cómo se mide el éxito de cada persona.

text: I think in that conversation what's important is also saying, 'I believe you can do all these things and I'm doing this to support you.' Or, 'I'm sharing this feedback because I believe in you.' Also saying that I'm here as support, as you are building that out, let me know what I can do to support you. We can jam on it together if it's helpful. Basically, I guess boil it down to one, restating your intention and why you are having that conversation to sharing that you are there to support them and offering your own help as well.
speaker: Melissa Tan
context: Lenny asks Melissa what specifically made her direct feedback feel caring rather than just critical. Melissa had earlier shared an example of giving tough feedback to a team member about moving faster. She explains that the key elements are stating your belief in the person, clarifying your supportive intentions, and actively offering to help them succeed rather than just pointing out problems.
text_ko: 그 대화에서 중요한 건 “당신이 이걸 다 해낼 수 있다고 믿고, 저는 그걸 돕기 위해 이 얘기를 하는 거예요”라고 말하는 거예요. 또는 “제가 피드백을 드리는 건 당신을 믿기 때문이에요”라고도요. 그리고 “이걸 만들어 가는 동안 제가 지원할게요. 어떻게 도와드리면 좋을지 알려 주세요. 필요하면 같이 고민해볼게요”라고 덧붙이는 게 중요해요. 한마디로 정리하면, 대화를 하는 의도와 이유를 다시 확인해주고 당신을 지지한다는 걸 전하며 구체적으로 도움을 제안하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我觉得在这种对话中，重要的是要说："我相信你能做好这些事情，我这样做是为了支持你。"或者说："我给你这些反馈是因为我相信你的能力。"还要告诉他们，在你推进这些事情的时候，我会在这里支持你，有什么需要帮忙的尽管说。如果有用的话，我们可以一起头脑风暴(jam)一下。基本上，我觉得可以归结为两点：第一，重申你的初衷和为什么要进行这次对话；第二，表达你会支持他们，并主动提供帮助。
text_es: Creo que en esa conversación lo importante es también decir: "Yo sé que puedes hacer todas estas cosas y estoy haciendo esto para apoyarte." O "Te estoy dando este feedback porque creo en ti." También decirle que estás ahí para apoyarlo, que mientras va desarrollando esto, que te diga en qué lo puedes ayudar. Podemos trabajar juntos en esto si te sirve. Básicamente, creo que se resume en dos cosas: uno, reafirmar tu intención y por qué estás teniendo esa conversación, y dos, mostrar que estás ahí para apoyarlo y ofrecer tu ayuda también.

text: I think it first starts with defining the scope that everyone is going to own and drive. So as you are setting up the team, it's important that each person on the team has scope that they can run independently and that they are excited to own and drive. So one example here is as I was leaving Dropbox, the finance team looked at our metrics and saw that each growth PM was bringing over a million in AR per year just from all the experiments.
speaker: Melissa Tan
context: Lenny asks Melissa how she creates a sense of ownership among team members. Melissa explains that ownership starts with giving each person meaningful scope they can run independently. She shares an example where Dropbox's finance team discovered each growth product manager was generating over $1 million in annual revenue through their experiments, demonstrating the power of giving people substantial ownership of important business outcomes.
vocabulary_highlights: scope that they can run independently
bringing over a million in AR
text_ko: 저는 먼저 팀원들이 각자 책임지고 주도할 '범위(scope)'를 정의하는 것에서 시작한다고 생각해요. 그래서 팀을 꾸릴 때는 팀원 각자가 독립적으로 운영할 수 있고 스스로 맡아 추진하는 데 신나는 범위를 주는 게 중요해요. 예를 들어 제가 Dropbox를 떠날 무렵 재무팀이 지표를 보니까, 각 그로스 PM(growth PM)이 실험들(experiments)만으로 연간 AR(annual revenue) 100만 달러 이상을 가져다주고 있었어요.
text_zh: 我觉得首先得把每个人要负责和推进的范围定清楚。所以在搭团队的时候，很重要的一点是团队里每个人都要有自己能独立运作的块，而且是他们愿意去承担和推进的。举个例子，我离开Dropbox的时候，财务团队看了看我们的数据，发现每个增长PM(growth PM)光是通过各种实验，一年就能带来超过一百万的AR收入。
text_es: Creo que lo primero es definir bien qué va a manejar cada quien y de qué se va a hacer cargo. Entonces cuando estás armando el equipo, es clave que cada persona tenga su área que pueda manejar de forma independiente y que realmente le emocione liderar. Te doy un ejemplo: cuando me iba de Dropbox, el equipo de finanzas revisó nuestras métricas y vio que cada PM de crecimiento estaba generando más de un millón en ingresos anuales nada más con todos los experimentos que hacían.

text: One of the most common pitfalls I'd say is not having, and I've alluded to this, not having a sense of the big picture from the start and not being strategic about what your go-to market strategy is going to be. Also, what is your pricing and packaging going to look like? So I wrote actually an article for the YC blog a few years ago with Abby about this because I felt like even at Dropbox, I mean it's a great thing. We were haphazardly finding amazing things. We had a freemium consumer product. Then we realized people wanted a Teams product, so we built a Teams product, but we never created that whole blueprint of what should it look like and what are the different connection points across consumer business.
speaker: Melissa Tan
context: Lenny asks Melissa about the most common mistakes companies make when starting to invest in growth. Melissa explains that many companies lack strategic thinking about their overall go-to-market approach and pricing from the beginning. She uses Dropbox as an example - while they successfully built both consumer and business products, they never created a clear blueprint for how these should connect and work together as a cohesive strategy.
text_ko: 제가 보기에 가장 흔한 함정 중 하나는, 앞서도 말했지만, 처음부터 큰 그림을 갖고 있지 않거나 시장 진입 전략(go-to-market strategy)을 전략적으로 세우지 않는 거예요. 또 가격 책정과 패키징(pricing and packaging)은 어떻게 할지도 고민해야 하고요. 그래서 몇 년 전에 Abby와 함께 YC 블로그에 이 주제로 글을 쓴 적이 있어요. 드롭박스도 비슷하다고 느꼈거든요. 물론 그 자체는 좋은 일이었지만 우리는 계획 없이 우연히 멋진 것들을 찾아내는 식으로 일했어요. 프리미엄(freemium) 기반의 소비자용 제품(consumer product)을 갖고 있다가 사람들이 팀용 제품(Teams product)을 원한다는 걸 알게 돼서 팀용 제품도 만들었죠. 그런데 그게 어떻게 보여야 하는지, 소비자 사업 전반에 걸친 다양한 연결 지점(connection points)은 무엇인지에 대한 전체 설계도(blueprint)는 만들지 않았어요.
text_zh: 我觉得最常见的一个坑就是，从一开始就没有大局观，对自己的市场策略(go-to market strategy)不够有规划。还有就是定价和产品包装(packaging)到底要怎么搞，也没想清楚。所以几年前我和Abby专门在YC的博客上写了篇文章聊这个事儿，因为我觉得就连Dropbox当时也是这样。当然这也不是坏事啦，我们就是这么摸着石头过河，偶然发现了一些很棒的东西。我们先做了免费增值(freemium)的个人产品，后来发现大家需要团队版，我们就又做了团队产品，但我们从来没有做过整体规划，没想过到底应该是什么样子，个人用户和企业用户之间应该怎么打通。
text_es: Una de las trampas más comunes, diría yo, es no tener, y ya he mencionado esto, no tener una visión del panorama general desde el principio y no ser estratégico con tu estrategia de salida al mercado (go-to market strategy). También, ¿cómo va a verse tu modelo de precios y empaquetado? De hecho, escribí un artículo para el blog de YC hace unos años con Abby sobre esto porque sentí que incluso en Dropbox, o sea, está genial. Estábamos encontrando cosas increíbles medio al azar. Teníamos un producto freemium para consumidores. Luego nos dimos cuenta de que la gente quería un producto para equipos, así que construimos un producto para equipos, pero nunca creamos ese blueprint completo de cómo debería verse y cuáles son los diferentes puntos de conexión entre el negocio consumer y business.
